awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Analysis of the Implementation and Effectiveness of Three Strikes Sentencing Reforms
awd_abstract_narration:
In 2012, California voters approved a ballot measure that modified the state's "Three Strikes and You're Out" law such that nonviolent and nonserious new felonies no longer trigger 25-to-life sentences, and certain third-strike inmates may petition to be resentenced as second-strikers and receive shortened sentences or early release.  This study will examine how court officials are implementing these changes, how contextual and individual factors influence resentencing outcomes, and the effectiveness of these changes at reducing prison populations and sentencing disparities. 

Semi-structured interviews with public defenders, prosecutors, and judges will examine how the reforms are being implemented in eight counties. Inmate data from the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) will be analyzed to determine risks associated with resentencing, how characteristics of inmates and the counties in which they were sentenced influence the chances of successful petitions for resentencing, and whether these changes have reduced disparities in sentencing outcomes. This study will contribute to research on policy implementation, prosecutorial and judicial discretion, sources of disparities in sentencing outcomes, and prisoner reintegration, thus furthering research within criminology, legal studies, and public policy. Findings will be disseminated through conference presentations and scholarly journal articles as well as online.

The large numbers of persons incarcerated as a result of Three Strikes and related policies, the geographic and racial disparities associated with these policies, and the effects on communities due to mass incarceration and reentry all suggest that findings of this study will have broad public and policy interest. Results and recommendations will be shared with criminal justice practitioners and policymakers. Better understanding of the effects of policy reforms can help policy makers make good decisions with regard to public safety, while making effective and efficient use of taxpayer dollars. The project will also provide training and mentoring to undergraduate students and enhance the research and teaching environment at Santa Clara University.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates how local court officials administer major statewide criminal justice policy reforms. It demonstrates how multiple interdisciplinary social scientific methods can be used to conduct rigorous assessments of policy changes. The mixed-methods approach combines original qualitative interview data with quantitative analysis of institutional statistical data.

 

This study adds insight into the role of prosecutorial and judicial decision making in the implementation of policy change and the role of legally relevant and extralegal factors in sentencing outcomes. It reveals dynamics within courtroom workgroups that affect the local implementation of statewide legislative mandates, as well as the substantive effects of one specific type of sentencing reform. The qualitative analyses uncover differences from county to county in the extent to which district attorneys and public defenders assigned to work on Proposition 36 cases agreed or disagreed on procedural and substantive goals and worked cooperatively or opposed one another. In addition, the analysis of interview data reveals that the structures, processes, allocation of resources, and staffing assignments established to carry out changes to the law, as well as the relationships between the courtroom workgroup members, varied widely between counties, and in turn influenced implementation processes as well as outcomes. The results from the quantitative analysis confirm that racial and ethnic disparities were present in the implementation of the original Three Strikes law in California, and indicate that the reforms introduced by Proposition 36 reduced the racial disparity in drug and property crime sentencing statewide. However, some notable disparities remain. Further analysis will uncover how these patterns varied from county to county, and the extent to which extralegal factors including political and socioeconomic characteristics of counties correspond to differences in outcomes before and after sentencing reforms.

 

In addition to supporting the generation of research products, this project has supported hands-on mentoring and training in qualitative and qualitative research methods to undergraduate students. Additional deliverables (journal publications) will be completed over the course of the next year using the data generated with support from this grant.
